title: Ferns at Rockport State Park
indexDescription: Common ferns of the Puget Sound region.
description: We drove north of Seattle to Rockport State Part for one of our Saturday walks.  The park is near the town of Concrete next to the Skagit River.  It has old growth in the lower part of the park.  We followed the Evergreen loop trail up the side hill. It's a great place to see a wide range of ferns.  On the way back we stopped in Concrete right off highway 2 for burgers at a classic style burger joint with Evis posters on the wall.

images.title: Maidenhair Fern
images.description: You find Maidenhair Fern (Adiantum pedatum) in moist locations next to streams.  This is my favorite fern.  They have black stems and delicate leaves.

images.title: Bracken Fern
images.description: You find Bracken Fern (Pteridium aquilinum) in full sun. This one is an unusually tall one; taller then me.

images.title: Oak Fern
images.description: Western Oak Fern (Gymnocarpium dryopteris) are small ferns found under old growth trees.  I first noticed them at lake Crescent Barns creek.

images.title: Licorice Fern
images.description: You normally find Licorice Fern (Polypodium glycyrrhiza) growing on the lower branches of maple trees.  In this case they were growing on the side hill.

images.title: Lady Fern
images.description: Lady Fern (Athyrium filix-femina) are common.  They have delicate fronds and in my home garden they fall apart in summer before the other types of ferns.

images.title: Trail Katheen
images.description: Kathleen on the Evergreen trail right before a short boardwalk.  She loves boardwalks.

images.title: Sword Fern
images.description: The Western Sword Fern (Polystichum munitum) is the most common fern in the Puget Sound forests.  It tolerates our dry summers. They are very hardly. I was thinning Sword Ferns from my garden by ripping them out of the ground. The roots are shallow.  Then I decided I wanted to put one in a different place and it took hold and thrived even after all the bad treatment.

images.title: Bridge and Creek
images.description: You can see a Sword fern in the foreground and some Maidenhair ferns under the bridge by the water.

images.title: Skunk Cabbage
images.description: You find Skunk Cabbage in very wet boggy areas.

images.title: Vanilla Leaf
images.description: Vanilla Leaf (Achlys triphylla) is common on the Puget Sound forest floor.  I bought one at the University Avenue farmer's market.  Now I have dozens in my garden.

images.title: Trillium
images.description: Western Trillium (Trillium ovatum) grows a big white flower in the middle. It is easy to find with its distinctive three leafs.

images.title: Evergreen Trail
images.description: The main trail in the park is called the Evergreen trail. The red parts are the steep parts.  Its about 3 miles long.

images.title: Deer Fern
images.description: Deer Fern (Blechnum spicant) is a smallish fern in moist locations. It grows a few taller black stems from the middle.

images.title: Big Stump
images.description: One of the old growth trees fell over exposing its giant root ball.
